monogr.title: The conspiracie, and tragedie of Charles Duke of Byron, Marshall of France : Acted lately in two playes, at the Black-Friers. Writted by George Chapman
monogr.author: Chapman, George

div.head: To my Honorable and Constant friend, Sir Tho: Walsingham, Knight: and to my much loued from his birth, the right toward and worthy Gentleman his sonne Thomas Walsingham, Esquire.
div.p: SIR, though I know, you euer stood little affected to these vnprofitable rites of Dedication; (which disposition in you, hath made me hetherto dispence with your right in my other impressions) yet, least the world may repute it a neglect in me, of so ancient and worthy a friend; (hauing heard your approbation of these in their presentment) I could not but prescribe them with your name; And that my affection may extend to your Posteritie, I haue entitled to it, herein, your hope and comfort in your generous sonne; whom I doubt not, that most reuerenc'd Mother of Manly Sciences; to whose instruction your vertuous care commits him; will so profitably initiate in her learned labours, that they will make him florish in his riper life, ouer the idle liues of our ignorant Gentlemen; and enable him to supply the Honorable places, of your name; extending your yeares, and his right noble Mothers (in the true comforts of his vertues) to the sight of much, and most happy Progenie; which most affectionately wishing; and diuiding these poore dismemberd Poems betwixt you, I desire to liue still in your gracefull loues; and euer,

closer.signed: The most assured at your commandements GEORGE CHAPMAN.
